embeds.title: Horror
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 1 :energy_hermit:  / The Hermit / Downfall

Apply 3 (5) **Bruise** :p_bruise: to ALL enemies.
**Bruise** :p_bruise: does not wear off this turn.

messages.content: good card, does a lot of damage for one energy and makes all of your bruise cards better. Its one of the better damage scaling cards hermit has lalso has a Noticeably powerful upgrade
Oh boy this sure is a designed card
it benefits a lot from having retain from coalescence or a runic pyramid
My main issue with it is that the more copies you have the better it gets, so getting 2 copies early means you can often never have your bruise run out for early fights
2-3 copies you can maintain bruise for most of the fight, if you have a small enough deck/enough draw
Some of my strongest runs are from having 3 copies of this and a small deck and just casually having 50+ bruise on all enemies
Snapshot becomes an absurd defensive tool at that point, IÂ´ve also had a run like that
I'd like to see it reworked to maybe 4(6) bruise, but instead of being bruise blur, it's more of a bruise tuck and roll. Apply 4(6) bruise to all enemies this turn and next turn.
It won't have the issue of getting infinitely better the more copies you have, which is one of my least favorite ways to design a card
probably Mwalls's favourite card
personally, I've never gotten much use out of this
but I can acknowledge that it is a crazy scaling tool in the right deck
and can turn your Snapshot into all the block you ever need
hmmm that's actually reasonable
but god damn would that be a downgrade
I mean, I think it might be warranted. Maybe give it block too but less horror so it isn't just horror?
thats too much text

so now instead of enter the gungeon, silent is playing escape the driver
Hmm, maybe make this be turn your bruise into temp strength next turn? So it still works similar to how it does, it just nerfs stacking it.
Just make it so that you only get strength from 1 enemy, so tbh it would probably have to lose aoe

Horror is a way to temporary scale your damage (usually for 2 turns, can be more with enough copies). I usually find it somewhat difficult to follow this up with several attacks to take advantage of the scaling, especially when I still only have three energy. Sometimes that's because you just didn't draw  it alongside enough attacks, other times it's because you are getting attacked for alot and need to block. I also find that since the value is spread over 2 turns, it can be a fairly awkward card in short fights that call for fast frontloaded damage/mitigation, and that you have to trade health to get full value from it. The most common reason I pick this up is to get some scaling to deal with hexaghost/guardian in act 1, though It's quite bad into both tri-sentries and gremlin nob, which holds it back. In act 2, it's also hard to find a turn to safely cast this with the damage numbers you are facing, though it can be quite good with aoe damage into gremlin leader and tri-slavers.

I also tend to find that such temporary damage scaling isn't that necessary for hermit, as the starting memento does a similar job, and you can find plenty of permanent scaling solutions with cards like determination, smoking barrel, and deadeye. I don't like to take one of these speculatively and hope to combo it with 2 other copies of itself to chain the bruise, too unreliable. I do think that this comboing with itself so well is an awkward design choice, and I would be in favor of smoothing the experience out by making it more like dodge and roll, though if you did that, there would no longer be any  support for a "bruise archetype".

Gets better once you have 4 energy to more easily follow it up, alongside card draw to find attacks to follow up, and with eternal form or called shot so that you can play more cheap attacks to benefit from the bruise. The bruise also pairs well with vulnerable, and can scale harder with additional sources of bruise like pistol whip and especially brawl. Multihits like spray n' pray and magnum take advantage of the bruise multiple times in an energy efficient way. The upgrade is excellent, an extra 2 damage for every attack/hit over both turns, which can add up very fast to be at least +8/+10 with the right synergies. Since horror encourages aggressively playing lots of cheap attacks, it also pairs well with any sustain relics, since you don't really want to be spending energy blocking during the bruise turns it gives you. That playstyle also naturally pairs well with all the ninja relics and pen nib. Runic pyramid is great so that you can apply this on safe turns and more easily combine it with lots of follow up attacks.
Your logic feels a little weird. It's bad because you might not draw the attacks/have energy to get value from it that turn, but it's also bad because it's split across 2 turns

I basically mean that if you're getting attacked for 20+, it's difficult to justify playing horror when you will probably need to spend most of your energy blocking rather than attacking.  Maybe you can get value from it next turn (depending on the enemies attack pattern), but it's a bit of a gamble on whether you will draw enough attacks to make it worth it when you could just play a front-loaded card and get guaranteed value. 

To get full value from horror, you want to play a bunch of attacks on both turns, but that's sometimes pretty awkward to do unless you can afford to lose a chunk of health. I think that a reasonable amount of the time, you get better value from playing a front-loaded attack instead like headshot, grudge, high caliber, or tracking shot. I put a high value on cards with consistent output, and I find horror to be inconsistent. You can also run into situations against enemies like book of stabbing where you really want to end the fight quickly, and you draw something like horror on turn 4 or 5 when you really want to end the fight and have it at low health already, and can't afford to wait a second turn to get full value from horror.

I think it's a reasonable pick if you have synergies, multiple copies of enervate/called shot/coalescence/eternal form, or if you are really hurting for scaling going into guardian/hexaghost. I don't take it very highly without those synergies though.
I would say cards comboing into themselves isn't always a negative cause you have a card like <catalyst> which combos into itself extremely well

messages.content: Catalyst won't be your only source of poison though, same for blur.

No one said nor implied that to be the case
It is by far the best one though

Yes and I don't like the design of catalyst. It's not as bad on silent who has a lot of draw and retain to set up turns to play multiple catalysts, but overall I still don't like catalyst design wise.
Collector talk, if you want to avoid it don't click this ||It's the same reason I proposed a goodbye nerf from instead of being 1 cost double (triple) your doom to being 2(1) cost double it||

I think cards like that are just way too reliant on when you draw them, and it gets so much worse when you have multiple copies. Unless your character has a ton of card manipulation and draw, it's really hard to use.
Hermit has almost no card manipulation, so I don't think a card like this works well balance wise

SIlent definitely occupies a space of being one of the most combo heavy characters in the game. They literally have cards that do nothing (reflex, tactician) if you don't draw them alongside the right enablers. They also have cards like setup, grand finale, finisher, burst, nightmare, and catalyst that are very time sensitive or involve setting up a big turn. Malaise often feels much stronger when you can combine it with one of the cards that can give you extra energy next turn.

For silent, I think that theme works really well due to the presence of well laid plans at uncommon, it's upgrade is just fantastic for increasing how often you can assemble these combos. You also have a ton of excellent card draw options like acrobatics, backflip, and prepared+ to help you get the right cards in combination with each other.

Hermit has some good card manipulation (luck of the draw, quickdraw if you have virtue to negate the drawback, fatal desire), but you won't always be able to find it, and they tend to need more synergies to fit in well with your deck. It is telling that I think runic pyramid is one of the absolute best boss relics for hermit, because it's so helpful to line up the right cards with the right turn (especially flash powder, gestalt, horror, and magnum).
Coalesence is also nice manipulation at common
Those are all card draw, not card manipulation. Hermit has 1 card manipulation card and it is coalescence.
And it's a low block card on a class with 0 access to dexterity
They do have maintenance+
they also have the one that draws all your strikes I think
but yeah, nothing as reliable as well laid plans or headbutt or seek or the defect one that returns your next played card to the top of your draw pile
That's not card manipulation
That one is arguably deck manipulation, but it's really bad so I don't count it
just because it's bad doesn't mean it's not that category of card
I guess. It's also just draw, which isn't really deck manipulation to me, deck manipulation is something like scry or headbutt that changes your draw pile/discard pile
Is draw considered deck manipulation?
It's a form of deck manipulation I guess.
